title: Sorry I have to do it !
content:
Dear all

Akzidenz Grotesk........ I am in the process of collecting a body of research relating to this pivotal sanserif,  
I have used the info from a recent help request, so thanks to all who donated.

I am still slightly confused over the name, the question I raise is,  
1. Does Grotesk, in German mean sanserif, or just simply grotesque (Eng.), if so, this can be taken to imply misshapen, malformed ugly etc. Its seem pretty regular to me and not at all ugly ?  
An earlier thread I had read ( in part ) seemed to indicate a meaning for Akzidentz which would convey a chance discovery.

Any ideas or thoughts will be greatly received.

Alan

Stefan. Doesn’t “grotesk” indeed translate as “grotesque”? I think this designation is indeed the result of the sans serif faces as being felt to be _strange_ compared to the usual and common serif faces of the time.  
Wouldn’t “sans serif” rather go by “serifenlose Linearantiqua” (at least that’s what I learned in typography class).

Sorry I haven’t replied sooner, work does tend to get in the way, annoyingly-!!  
Endre, Interestingly I think I would go for Bertholds as well, but I have to ask myself why ?  
Aesthetically you could argue the differences are minimal between several early Grotesks, so my choice is most likely based on  
the originality of Bertholds AG, that said my research has revealed other foundries which also produced early SanSerifs could have also figured in the creation of this seminal face so one could argue (originality, whats that ?).  
Its strange also that one of the names mentioned several times in various pieces of research is Vincent Figgins, he is credited with amongst others, Giza, an Egyptian style face (similar to Rockwell). I say strange because my family come from a part of London not far away from where he had his foundry and our names are similar.

re the “Grotesk” meaning I think Jan has hit the nail, so to speak ! I wonder if the idea was, this new face was so “modern” Berthold jokingly played along ?  
A friend of mine who is taking typography degree intimated similar

Many thanks to all who have contributed

Alan

Dear Alan!

Regarding » Grotesk « as German native speaker (as you may note my English skills are worst) I have a few additional remarks.

In german we have (had) three modes to name a »Sans Serif«:

Grotesk  
Sans Serif  
serifenlose (= Sans Serif) (Linear-) Antiqua

The semantic origin of the term » Grotesk « is the French language of the 17th century. The term (grotesque) first was used in visual arts to express an unnatural combination of parts of humans, animals and plants. This term etymologically was borrowed from the Italian » grottesco « = » part of a cave «, meaning antique cave paintings, antique cuneiform writing etc.

In 1832 the London typesetter and type founder Vincent Figgins (1766–1844) created a typeface (only uppercase) called » Two-line Great Primer Sans-serif «. He was the first using the term » Sans Serif «. In the same year William Thorowgood published a typeface (uppercase and lowercase) which became known as » grotesque «.

Arround 1880 the German Typesetter Ferdinand Theinhard created a four weights typeface called » Royal Grotesk « for publications of the » Königlich-Preußischen Akademie der Wissenschaften zu Berlin « (Royal Prussian Academy of Science Berlin). This was the moment when the » Grotesk « became popular in Germany. 1908 Herman Berthold took over the Theinhard Foundry and continued to sell the » Royal Grotesk « till the end of the monarchy in 1918. After that Berthold sold the » Royal Grotesk « as » Akzidenz Grotesk «.
